fields.Transcription:
Hallo, I bin Â´d Anne und I komm ausÂ´m SchwobalÃ¤ndle. Des isch in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg. Schwaben. So rund um Schtuddgart drum rum. Oder wie mir Schwoba saga dÃ¤da: rund um Schduagard.

 

SÂ´gibt viele Diskussiona, ob SchwÃ¤bisch jetz a eigana Sprache isch, oder edd, weil eigentlich ischÂ´s bloÃŸ an Dialekt. Aber i denk, vor allem sÂ´alde SchwÃ¤bisch isch eigentlich a Sprache fÃ¼r sich und i mÃ¶cht euch zeiga, warum i des denk.

 

NÃ¤mmer zum Beispiel mol des Wort fÃ¼r diese Frucht. Auf Hochdeutsch sagt ma: â€eine Erdbeere.â€œ Mir Schwoba saged: â€ a Breschtlingâ€œ. Zumindescht die alde Schwoba saged des in de gleine DÃ¶rfla auf dr SchwÃ¤bischa Alb. Do isch SchwÃ¤bisch wirklich noch am LÃ¤ba, obwohl mirâ€¦in der Schule mÃ¼ssmer Hochdeutsch schwÃ¤tza. Aber so in der Familie, vor allem mitÂ´m, mitÂ´m Ehne, do schwÃ¤tzt ma no SchwÃ¤bisch.

 

I bin schdolzer Schwabe, vor allem weil i denk, dassÂ´d schwÃ¤bischa Kultur ganz besonders schÃ¶n isch. Mir sinn a ganz warma Kultur, mit kommad gern zamma in dr Familie und in viele Teile vom SchwobalÃ¤ndle isch dr Glaube an Jesus Chrischtus eigentlich no richtig am LÃ¤ba. DÂ´Landeskirche isch aktiv und am LÃ¤ba, junge Loit, alde Loit, jeder isch mehr oder  weniger in dr Kirch involviert. Und des hat au historische GrÃ¼nde. Weil vor ogfÃ¤hr zwoihonderd Johr hÃ¤nnd dÂ´Schwoba beschlossa: â€Mir wÃ¤llad d`Bibl au fÃ¼r uns sÃ¤lber lÃ¤sa. Mir wÃ¤llad edd bloÃŸ am Sonndag vom Pfarrer hÃ¶ra, was der aus am Word uns erklÃ¤rt. Desch schee ond guat, aber mir wÃ¤lladÂ´s fÃ¼r uns sÃ¤lber lÃ¤sa.â€œ

 

No hÃ¤nnd se begonna, Mittwochobnds, in der Biblschdund, selbr sÂ´Word Goddes zum lÃ¤sa und des auf ihr eigenes LÃ¤ba anzumwenda und des sieht ma bis hoit in de glaine DÃ¶fla auf dr SchwÃ¤bischa Alb. Jeden Mittwoch isch Biblschdund, oder au oifach bloÃŸ â€Schdundâ€œ. Do goht ma no umÂ´s Word Goddes zum lÃ¤sa und aufÂ´s aigene LÃ¤ba anzumwenda.

 

Deshalb bin i stolzer Schwabe.

 

Mir sagad au: â€Mir kÃ¶nnad alles, auÃŸer Hochdeutsch.â€œ â€“ und in dem Sinne: viel SpaÃŸ beim SchwÃ¤bischlerna!

 

Ade!
fields.Translation:
Hello, IÂ´m Anne and IÂ´m from Swabia. ThatÂ´s in Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg (German province). Swabia. More or less around Stuttgart. Or, as us Swabians say: around â€Schduagardâ€œ.

Â 

There are many discussions whether Swabian is a language on its own or not, because actually itÂ´s just a dialect. But I think that the old Swabian especially, is a language on its own and I want to show you why I think so.

Â 

LetÂ´s take the word for this fruit (strawberry) for example. In high German one would say: â€œeine Erdbeereâ€. Us Swabians say: â€œa Breschtlingâ€. At least the old Swabians in the small villages on the Swabian Alb. There, Swabian is still really alive, although weâ€¦in  school we have to speak high German. But with your family, especially with your grand-father, you still speak SchwÃ¤bisch. Â 

Â 

I am proud to be a Swabian, because I think that the Swabian culture is particularly nice. We have a very warm culture, we love to get together with extended family and in many parts of Swabia the faith in Jesus Christ is still very alive.   The church there is very active and alive, young people, old people, everyone is more or less involved in church. And this also had historical reasons. Because about 200 years ago, the Swabians decided: â€We want to read the Word of God for ourselves. We donÂ´t only want to hear from the preacher on Sunday, what he explains from the Word (of God). ThatÂ´s fine, but we also want to read it for ourselves.â€So they began reading the Word of God on their own and applying it to their lives on Wednesday evenings, in the â€œBiblschdundâ€ (â€œBible hourâ€). And this is something you see until today in little villages on the Swabian Alb. Every Wednesday is â€œBiblschdundâ€œ, or simply â€Schdundâ€œ (â€hourâ€œ). ThatÂ´s where you go to read the Word of God and to apply it to your own life.ThatÂ´s why IÂ´m proud to be a Swabian.We have a saying â€We can do anything but speak high German.â€œ - In this sense: Have fun learning Swabian!Bye.
